author: La rÃ©daction avec AFP
title: Religion. Lâ€™expulsion dâ€™un imam de Toulouse confirmÃ©e par le Conseil dâ€™Ã‰tat
text: Religion Lâ€™expulsion dâ€™un imam de Toulouse confirmÃ©e par le Conseil dâ€™Ã‰tat Lâ€™imam de la Grande mosquÃ©e de Toulouse avait Ã©tÃ© condamnÃ© des propos haineux envers les juifs lors dâ€™un prÃªche. Le Conseil dâ€™Ã‰tat a confirmÃ© jeudi lâ€™expulsion dâ€™un imam de Toulouse prononcÃ©e en avril pour des propos haineux envers les juifs, selon une dÃ©cision consultÃ©e par lâ€™AFP. Le Conseil est allÃ© dans le sens de la justice administrative, qui avait rejetÃ© le recours en urgence dÃ©posÃ© par Mohamed TataÃ¯at. Cet imam de la Grande mosquÃ©e de Toulouse avait Ã©tÃ© condamnÃ© en 2022 Ã  quatre mois dâ€™emprisonnement avec sursis pour avoir tenu lesdits propos lors dâ€™un prÃªche. Mohamed TataÃ¯at avait Ã©tÃ© arrÃªtÃ© Ã  son domicile le 19 avril, sur autorisation du juge des libertÃ©s et de la dÃ©tention, [puis expulsÃ©](/faits-divers-justice/2024/04/20/expulsion-vers-l-algerie-d-un-imam-condamne-pour-provocation-a-la-haine). Ses avocats avaient alors dÃ©posÃ© un recours devant le juge des rÃ©fÃ©rÃ©s, dÃ©nonÃ§ant une expulsion expÃ©ditive et ne tenant pas compte de son comportement exemplaire depuis le prÃªche dÃ©criÃ©, prononcÃ© en 2017. Ce recours a toutefois Ã©tÃ© rejetÃ© par le tribunal administratif de Paris, dÃ©cision confirmÃ©e jeudi par le Conseil dâ€™Ã‰tat. Vers un nouveau recours ArrivÃ© en France en 1985, Mohamed TataÃ¯at avait rejoint Toulouse deux ans plus tard pour exercer Ã  la mosquÃ©e du quartier Empalot. Le ministre de lâ€™IntÃ©rieur [GÃ©rald Darmanin](/p/gerald-darmanin), qui avait signÃ© lâ€™arrÃªtÃ© dâ€™expulsion, a pris note de la dÃ©cision du Conseil dâ€™Ã‰tat sur X (ex-Twitter), en se fÃ©licitant de la Â« fermetÃ© Â» et de lâ€™Â« efficacitÃ© de la loi immigration Â». Vincent Brengarth, lâ€™avocat de Mohamed TataÃ¯at, a annoncÃ© son intention de dÃ©poser un nouveau recours, sur le fond cette fois, et assurÃ© que son client avait Â« poursuivi sans le moindre incident ses prÃªches depuis 2017 Â» et Â« quâ€™aucune menace Ã  lâ€™ordre public nâ€™(avait) Ã©tÃ© dÃ©montrÃ©e par lâ€™administration Â». Dans son ordonnance fin avril, le tribunal estimait que les propos de Mohamed TataÃ¯at Â« constituent une provocation explicite et dÃ©libÃ©rÃ©e Ã  la discrimination, Ã  la haine et Ã  la violence contre un groupe de personnes - en lâ€™espÃ¨ce, les Juifs -, et revÃªtent une rÃ©sonance et une gravitÃ© particuliÃ¨re depuis lâ€™attaque du 7 octobre 2023 menÃ©e par le Hamas Ã  lâ€™encontre dâ€™IsraÃ«l Â».

author: Devan Cole and Holmes Lybrand, CNN
title: Former Trump adviser Peter Navarro sentenced to 4 months in jail for defying congressional subpoena | National Politics | news8000.com
text: Washington (CNN) â€” Peter Navarro was sentenced Thursday to four months in jail for contempt of Congress after defying a subpoena related to the congressional investigation into the January 6, 2021, US Capitol attack. Navarro was convicted on two counts of contempt of Congress in September for not complying with a subpoena from the House select committee that investigated the attack. The judge overseeing Navarroâ€™s case said Thursday that the former Trump adviserâ€™s sentence is of his â€œown makingâ€ as he tore into Navarro for claiming that his prosecution was politically motivated. â€œI guess what bothers me ultimately is that here we are after a year and a half plus and you still want to suggest to me that this is a political prosecution. You want me to believe this is a political prosecution,â€ US District Judge Amit Mehta said during the sentencing hearing, raising his voice. â€œWhen the evidence is completely to the contrary.â€ â€œYou are not a victim. You are not the object of a political prosecution,â€ the judge said. â€œThese are the circumstances of your own making.â€ Mehta also fined Navarro $9,500. Navarro quickly appealed the case on Thursday to the DC Circuit Court of Appeals. His attorneys have long said they plan to file an appeal to raise issues related to his claim that he didnâ€™t comply with the subpoena because Trump had invoked executive privilege. Each count carries a mandatory minimum sentence of one month in prison, but prosecutors had asked Mehta to sentence Navarro to six months for each count â€“ running concurrently â€“ and fine him $200,000. They told the judge last week that a sentence of one month apiece for the two counts â€œis insufficient to account for, punish, and deter the Defendantâ€™s criminal offenses,â€ arguing that Navarroâ€™s decision to not comply with the subpoenas was akin to the conduct of some of the people who participated in the riot. â€œThe Defendant, like the rioters at the Capitol, put politics, not country, first, and stonewalled Congressâ€™s investigation,â€ prosecutors wrote. â€œThe Defendant chose allegiance to former President Donald Trump over the rule of law.â€ Navarroâ€™s conviction and sentence represents another key victory for the now-disbanded House January 6 committee in its efforts to have the Justice Department criminally pursue individuals who refused to cooperate with its probe. Former Trump adviser Steve Bannon was convicted in 2022 on two contempt counts and later sentenced to four months in prison. Bannonâ€™s case is currently on appeal. Navarroâ€™s attorneys are seeking a sentence of no more than six months of probation for each count, and they asked Mehta last week to pause the sentence he imposes as they appeal the conviction. A speedy trial Navarroâ€™s trial last September moved quickly, with it taking less than a day for the jury to hear all the evidence in the case. Prosecutors put just three witnesses on the stand, all former staff members of the House January 6 committee. The Justice Department used its testimony to make the case that the committee had good reason to subpoena Navarro and that he was informed repeatedly of its demands. Prosecutor Elizabeth Aloi told the jury in closing arguments that Navarro â€œhad knowledge about a plan to delay the activities of Congress on January 6,â€ and that he was â€œmore than happyâ€ to air that knowledge in public remarks, but not to the House committee. Navarroâ€™s attorneys did not put on any witnesses of their own, instead focusing on part of the contempt charge that required a showing that Navarro was willful and deliberate in his decision not to comply with the subpoena â€“ meaning that his lack of compliance was not the result of an inadvertent mistake or accident. Navarro has insisted that he didnâ€™t comply with the subpoena at the direction of Trump, who he claimed invoked executive privilege in the matter. But ahead of trial, Mehta concluded that Navarro had not carried his burden in proving that Trump had formally asserted a privilege or a testimonial immunity that would have allowed his former aide to not even appear to answer the committeeâ€™s questions. The former aide has said he plans to raise that issue and others on appeal. â€œThe appeal of this case will definitely answer what is required of a former President to invoke executive privilege as to their senior advisors and no future advisor will be in the same position of not knowing that the President they served had not properly invoked the privilege,â€ his attorneys wrote in court papers. The federal appeals court in DC is currently considering Bannonâ€™s bid to overturn his own contempt of Congress conviction. During oral arguments last year, some members of a three-judge panel handling the appeal appeared skeptical of arguments advanced by Bannonâ€™s attorney that the trial court judge who oversaw Bannonâ€™s criminal case erred when they declined to let him assert executive privilege as part of his defense, and that the ex-adviser was simply acting on the advice of his then-attorney when he didnâ€™t comply with the subpoena. This story and headline have been updated to reflect additional developments. The-CNN-Wire â„¢ & Â© 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved. title: "Over 7 feet": Watch trending video of very tall man dancing at home
text: "He's Almost Reaching the Ceiling": Nigerian Man Who's Over 7ft Tall Dances at Home in Viral Video - A video of a very tall Nigerian man has gone viral, sparking lots of hilarious reactions from internet users - The young man who is 7ft2 tall was seen in the viral video dancing energetically while flaunting his height - Netizens who watched the video took to the comments section to drop remarks about his height and physique PAY ATTENTION: [The 2024 Business Leaders Awards Present Entrepreneurs that Change Nigeria for the Better. Check out their Stories!](https://corp.legit.ng/legit-business-names-2024) An intriguing video of a young Nigerian man who is 7ft2 tall has stunned many viewers on the [TikTok](https://www.legit.ng/tags/tiktok/) app The young man began making waves on the app after posting the clip that greatly revealed his height. Nigerian man causes frenzy with his height The young man identified on TikTok as @ [rupeekolawole](https://vm.tiktok.com/ZMM4dNxAa/) was sighted in the clip dancing energetically while filming himself. PAY ATTENTION: Share your outstanding story with our editors! Please reach us through info@corp.legit.ng! [He danced](https://vm.tiktok.com/ZMMX7RMy5/) to an Afrobeat song playing in the [background](https://www.legit.ng/1174941-background-study-research-write.html) and his dance steps synced with the rhythm of the song. Amid doubts about his nationality, he reiterated that he was a Nigerian although some [people](https://www.legit.ng/people/) still failed to believe him. He captioned the video: â€œI told yall that I am from Nigeria.â€ Reactions trail video of tall man dancing Funny netizens on [TikTok](https://www.legit.ng/tags/tiktok/) opined that the young man was too tall and looked like he would break while dancing. ErnÃ©st MÃºlÃºx said: â€œBro dancing for his life.â€ Awesome V reacted: â€œU just make me remember one tree laidat (Igi agunmaniye).â€ Arinze Michael said: â€œI thought he was falling.â€ @classybrown said: â€œBro dancing in capital letters.â€ Alex reacted: â€œYou don't need to chase any of your dreams, you walk to them.â€ Janemccall said: â€œGive him one of the indomitable name which one fit am.â€ @aderubysapphy3 reacted: â€œThis height is something else.â€ @iceonmineq reacted: 'No matter how the palm tree grows it can never be taller than an iroko tree, I donâ€™t know how it relates o but na Wetin come my head now." @Vini Godson added: "Nothing wey you wan tell me Bro must be in a long distance relationship." @oyi said: â€œEven him hand long pass my leg.â€ JONATHAN4234 said: â€œHe's taller than the comment section.â€ Watch the video below: Tall girl flaunts her shape and height Meanwhile, Legit.ng previously reported that a beautiful tall lady went viral on TikTok after [flaunting her height. ](https://www.legit.ng/people/1544503-na-spec-tall-girl-slim-body-flaunts-shape-viral-video-netizens-praise-physique/) Tamara's height and slender physique which were glaring in a video made netizens admire her greatly. author: /news/author/thefly
title: IGM Biosciences halting further development of imvotamab and IGM-2644
text:
IGM Biosciences ([IGMS](https://www.tipranks.com/stocks/igms)) announced a strategic update to halt further development of imvotamab, an IgM-based CD20 X CD3 bispecific antibody T cell engager, and IGM-2644, an IgM-based CD38 X CD3 bispecific antibody T cell engager, for autoimmune diseases. â€œInterim data from the Phase 1b studies of imvotamab in rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus show that the depth and consistency of B cell depletion is insufficient to meet our high bar for success. Due to these findings, we have decided to discontinue further development of imvotamab. I would like to thank the patients and investigators who have participated in the imvotamab clinical studies as well as our employees for their commitment to transforming the lives of patients living with autoimmune diseases. Concurrent with discontinuation of the imvotamab program, IGM-2644 is also being terminated due to strategic considerations,â€ said Mary Beth Harler, M.D., Chief Executive Officer of IGM Biosciences.

author: Rose Aguilar
title: Advocates say Newsom's order on encampments punishes the poor
text:
Advocates say Newsom's order on encampments punishes the poor
On this edition of Your Call, we discuss the response to California Governor Gavin Newsom's executive order calling on state and local officials to clear homeless encampments.
In late June, the six conservative Justices on the Supreme Court ruled that cities can fine and arrest homeless people for sleeping in public spaces, even if they have nowhere else to go.
Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass slammed the ruling saying it must not be used as an excuse for cities across the country to arrest their way out of the problem or hide the homelessness crisis in neighboring cities or in jail.
San Francisco Mayor London Breed said the city is planning a "very aggressive sweep." She recently announced a directive ordering all city departments and staff to offer unhoused people bus tickets out of town before offering other services, including shelter or housing.
Attorney Andrea Henson, who has lived in encampments to protect the rights of her unhoused clients during encampment removals, described the order as "ill-informed" and says it "punishes the poor." Henson was
arrested yesterday while protesting a sweep in Oakland.
California is home to
about 123,000 unsheltered people living in tents, trailers, cars and makeshift shelters. Where are these people supposed to go?
Guests:
Andrea Henson, attorney and executive director at
Where Do We Go
LeaJay Harper, former resident at the Wood Street encampment in Oakland
Sharon Rapport, California state policy director at
the Corporation for Supportive Housing
Resources:
The New York Times:
Clear Encampments? Mind Your Own Business, Los Angeles Tells Newsom.
CalMatters:
Gavin Newsom orders state agencies to move homeless people out of camps â€” but to where?
San Francisco Chronicle:
Breedâ€™s sweeps of S.F. homeless encampments hit snag as federal judge orders more training
ABC:
There are 2 operations working to clear SF homeless encampments. Here's the difference

author: @WAFB
title: More shelter beds available for upcoming severe cold weather
text: More shelter beds available for upcoming severe cold weather BATON ROUGE, La. (WAFB) - A Baton Rouge area homeless shelter is preparing to open more beds in anticipation of the extremely cold weather forecasted for next week. The Society of St. Vincent de Paul released the following news release about their plans: St. Vincent de Paulâ€™s Bishop Ott Shelter Program has initiated its plan for the upcoming cold nights (39 degrees & below). We will expand bed capacity for men, women, children, and families experiencing homelessness during the cold days and nights to come. We provide day and night shelter services to men, women, and children, and annually, provide over 30,000 guest nights of shelter. As a community-leading homeless services provider, our shelter program operates four-night shelter programs (with a 200+ bed capacity) and an emergency overflow night shelter. We currently operate two emergency shelters for men, one for women and children, and one for families and children. We expect to fill all beds and will make room for emergency cases in our overflow shelter. Individuals in need of cold weather shelter can come by our main shelter complex at 1623 Convention Street, Baton Rouge, LA 70802 to apply for shelter. We will begin accepting people in need for cold weather beds between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 4:00 p.m. this Friday, January 12th. We will continue accepting individuals in need of shelter throughout the weekend, and will also be open Monday and throughout the entire week to accommodate the needs of those seeking shelter and services. We encourage individuals in need to seek shelter as early as possible. They can also call (225) 383-7341 or (225) 383-7837 for more information. In addition to providing shelter, our programs offer services to help individuals break the cycle of homelessness and become self-sufficient. Our programs have a good record of helping the homeless obtain employment, affordable housing and other things necessary to become self-sufficient. Cold temperatures always put extra stress on the limited resources and volunteers of our small non-profit. Individuals interested in assisting the homeless can do so by supporting current shelter needs. We currently need: men, women and childrenâ€™s pajamas and underwear; womenâ€™s sleeping gowns; rain gear (ponchos and umbrellas); reading glasses (all strengths); slippers; toiletry items such as deodorant, body wash, and lotion; twin size blankets; paper products (napkins, paper towels, toilet paper); disposable cups, plates, bowls, knives, forks, and spoons. These items can be dropped off on Monday at our main location at 1623 Convention Street. Call us at 383-7837 for more information. In addition, in these difficult economic times, financial contributions are needed more than ever and can be made to the Society of St. Vincent de Paul at P.O. Box 127, Baton Rouge, LA 70821-0127 or online at [www.svdpbr.org](http://www.svdpbr.org/). RELATED STORIES [Click here](mailto:typo@wafb.com) to report a typo. Copyright 2024 WAFB. All rights reserved.
